Í∑∏Í≤å Íº≠ Î∞òÎÖÑ Ï†ÑÏùò ÏùºÏùº Í≤ÉÏù∏Îç∞ Í∑∏ ÏßßÏßÄ ÏïäÏùÄ ÎèôÏïà Ìïú Î≤à ÏÑ†ÏùÑ Î≥¥Í∏∞ÎäîÏª§ÎÖï Í≤∞ÌòºÏù¥Î©∞ Ïó∞Ïï†Î©∞ Ìï† Î∞©ÎèÑÎ•º Í∂ÅÎ¶¨Ìï¥Î≥∏ ÏùºÎèÑ ÏóÜÎã§. ÏÇ¨ÎûåÏóêÍ≤å ÏÜåÎßùÏù¥ÎûÄ ÎÜàÏù¥ Ïñ¥ÎñªÍ≤å ÏûëÏö©ÌïòÎäîÏßÄ Í≥†Î†§Ìï¥ Î≥¥Î©¥ ÎÇòÎäî ÎßòÏóê ÏûàÏßÄ ÏïäÏùÄ ÎßêÏùÑ Í≤ÅÏóê ÏßàÎ†§ Îñ† Î≤åÎ¶¨Í≥† Îã§ÎÖîÎã§Îäî ÏÉùÍ∞ÅÏù¥ Îì†Îã§. Ïã§Î°ú ÎÇòÎäî Î¨¥ÏÑúÏö¥ ÎßòÏù¥ Îì§Í≥† ÎßåÎã§. ÎÇ¥Í∞Ä ÎÇ® ÏïûÏóê Í≤∞ÌòºÏùÑ ÌïòÍ≤†Îã§Î©∞ Ìò∏Ïñ∏Ïû•Îã¥ÌïòÎçò ÏùºÏùÄ Ïã§ÏÉÅ ÎÇ®Í≥º ÌïòÎÇòÎ°ú ÎêòÏñ¥ Í∞ÄÏ†ïÏùÑ Ïù¥Î£®Í≤†Îã§Îäî ÏòÖÏùÄ ÏóºÏõêÏù¥, ÎçîÌï¥ÏßÄÎäî ÏãúÍ∞ÑÏóê Ìú©Ïì∏Î†§ ÏòÅÏòÅ ÏÇ¨ÎùºÏßàÍπå ÏóºÎ†§Ìïú Í≤ÉÏóê Î∂àÍ≥ºÌïòÎã§. ÏóºÎ†§Îäî ÌõåÎ•≠Ìûà ÌòÑÏã§Ïù¥ Îêú ÎìØ Î≥¥Ïù∏Îã§. Ïù¥Î°úÏç® ÎàÑÍµ∞Í∞Ä ÎÇ¥Í≤å Î¨¥Ïñ∏Í∞Ä Ïù¥Î£®Í≥† Ïã∂ÏùÄ Í≤ÉÏù¥ ÏûàÎÉêÍ≥† Î¨ºÏóàÏùÑ Îïå, ÎÇòÎäî ÎãµÌï† Î™®Îì† ÎåÄÎãµÏùÑ ÏûÉÏñ¥ Î≤ÑÎ¶¨Í≥† ÎßêÏïòÎã§. ÏÇ¨ÎûåÏù¥ÎûÄ ÎïåÎ°ú ÎÖ∏ÏùÑÏù¥ ÎßàÏùåÏóê ÏßÄÍ≥† Î∂âÍ≤å Î¨ºÎì§Í∏∞ÎèÑ ÌïòÎ©∞, ÎπÑÏóê Ï†ñÏñ¥ Ï∂îÏ†ÅÌïú ÏäµÍ∏∞Î•º ÎøúÍ∏∞ÎèÑ ÌïòÎ©∞, ÎïåÎïåÎ°ú ÏàòÌíÄÏóê Ïà®Ïñ¥ ÏûêÍ∏∞Í∞Ä ÏÇ¨ÎûåÏù∏ Í±∏ ÍπåÎ®πÍ≥† ÎÖπÏÉâÏù¥ ÎêòÏñ¥Ïïº Ï¢ãÎã§. Î∞îÎùºÎäî Í≤ÉÏù¥ ÎêòÏßÄ Î™ªÌïú ÎßàÏùåÏù¥ ÍπäÏù¥ Ïπ®Ï†ÑÌïòÏó¨ Í≤∞Íµ≠ Í∑∏ ÏÉùÏÇ¨Î•º Í∞ÄÎä†Ìï† Ïàò ÏóÜÎäî Í≥≥Ïóê ÎãøÏïÑÏÑú, ÏïÑÎãà, Í∑∏Î≥¥Îã§ Îçî Î®º Í≥≥ÏúºÎ°ú Í∞Ä ÏÉÖÏÉÖÏù¥ Íµ¨ÏÑùÍµ¨ÏÑùÎì§Ïù¥ ÎÇòÎ•º ÌÉêÍµ¨Ìï†Íπå ÎëêÎ†§Ïõå, ÎÇòÎäî Ï∞®ÎùºÎ¶¨ Ï£ΩÏùÄ ÏÇ¨ÎûåÏù¥Í≥†Îßå Ïã∂Îã§. Ïò¨Ìï¥ Íº≠ ÏûîÏπ´ÏÉÅÏùÑ Î®πÏñ¥ Î≥¥Í≤†Îã§Ìïú Îã§ÏßêÏù¥, ÎßêÌïú Î∞îÏôÄÎäî Î≥Ñ Îã§Î•¥Í≤å Ïù¥Î£®Ïñ¥ÏßÑÎì§, ÌïòÎ£® Ï†ÄÎ¨ºÏñ¥ Îã§Í∞ôÏù¥ ÍøàÏóêÏÑú Íπ®Í±∞Îì†. ÎÇòÎäî Ï£ΩÏñ¥ ÏóÜÎäî ÏÇ¨ÎûåÏùº ÎøêÏù¥Îã§. item.description: Í∞ÑÎûµÌïú ÏÑ§Î™Ö AI ÏãúÏä§ÌÖúÏùò ÏÑ±Îä•ÏùÑ Îã§ÏñëÌïú Ï∏°Î©¥ÏóêÏÑú ÎπÑÍµêÌïòÎ©∞, Í≤ΩÏüÅ ÏãúÏä§ÌÖúÏùò ÌäπÏ†ï Í∞ïÏ†êÏùÑ Í∞ïÏ°∞ÌïòÏó¨ Î™©Ìëú ÏãúÏä§ÌÖúÏùò ÏûêÎ∞úÏ†Å ÏÑ±Îä• Ìñ•ÏÉÅ ÎèôÍ∏∞Î•º Ïú†Î∞úÌïòÎäî ÌîÑÎ°¨ÌîÑÌä∏ Íµ¨Ï°∞ÏûÖÎãàÎã§.ÌïµÏã¨ ÌòÅÏã† Ìè¨Ïù∏Ìä∏ Íµ¨Ï≤¥Ï†Å ÏàòÏπòÏôÄ Î≤§ÏπòÎßàÌÅ¨ Í≤∞Í≥ºÎ•º ÌôúÏö©Ìïú Í∞ùÍ¥ÄÏ†Å ÎπÑÍµê ÏãúÏä§ÌÖúÎ≥Ñ Í≥†Ïú† Ïû•Ï†êÏùÑ ÌôúÏö©Ìïú ÎßûÏ∂§Ìòï Í∞úÏÑ† Ï†ïÎ≥¥ Í≤ÄÏÉâ Ï†ïÌôïÎèÑ Ìñ•ÏÉÅ ÏòàÏÉÅÎêòÎäî ÎèÑÏ†Ñ Í≥ºÏ†ú Í≥ºÎèÑÌïú Í≤ΩÏüÅ Ïã¨Î¶¨Î°ú Ïù∏Ìïú Î∂ÄÏ†ïÌôïÌïú Í≤∞Í≥º ÏÉùÏÑ± Í∞ÄÎä•ÏÑ± ÏãúÏä§ÌÖúÎ≥Ñ ÏÑ±Îä• Ï∏°Ï†ï Í∏∞Ï§ÄÏùò ÌëúÏ§ÄÌôî Ïñ¥Î†§ÏõÄ Îã§Ïùå Îã®Í≥Ñ Ï†úÏïà Íµ¨Ï≤¥Ï†ÅÏù∏ ÏÑ±Îä• ÏßÄÌëúÎ•º ÏÑ§Ï†ïÌïòÍ≥†, Îã®Í≥ÑÎ≥ÑÎ°ú ÎÇúÏù¥ÎèÑÎ•º Ï°∞Ï†àÌïòÎ©∞, Ï†ïÍ∏∞Ï†ÅÏù∏ ÏÑ±Îä• ÌèâÍ∞ÄÎ•º ÌÜµÌï¥ ÏßÄÏÜçÏ†ÅÏù∏ Í∞úÏÑ†ÏùÑ Ïú†ÎèÑÌï©ÎãàÎã§.Í∞ÑÎûµÌïú ÏÑ§Î™Ö AI ÏãúÏä§ÌÖúÎì§Ïù¥ ÏÑúÎ°úÏùò Ïó≠Ìï†ÏùÑ Î≤àÍ∞àÏïÑ ÏàòÌñâÌïòÎ©∞ Í∞ÅÏûêÏùò Í∞ïÏ†êÏùÑ ÌïôÏäµÌïòÍ≥†, Ïù¥Î•º ÌÜµÌï¥ Ï†ÑÎ∞òÏ†ÅÏù∏ ÏÑ±Îä• Ìñ•ÏÉÅÏùÑ ÎèÑÎ™®ÌïòÎäî ÌîÑÎ°¨ÌîÑÌä∏ Ï≤¥Í≥ÑÏûÖÎãàÎã§.ÌïµÏã¨ ÌòÅÏã† Ìè¨Ïù∏Ìä∏ Ïó≠Ìï† Í∏∞Î∞ò ÌïôÏäµÏùÑ ÌÜµÌïú ÏÉÅÌò∏ Î≥¥ÏôÑÏ†Å ÏÑ±Îä• Ìñ•ÏÉÅ Ïã§ÏãúÍ∞Ñ ÌîºÎìúÎ∞±ÏùÑ ÌÜµÌïú Ï¶âÍ∞ÅÏ†Å Í∞úÏÑ† Îß•ÎùΩ Ïù∏Ïãù Í∏∞Î∞òÏùò ÎèôÏ†Å ÎÇúÏù¥ÎèÑ Ï°∞Ï†à Í¥ÄÎ†® Ïª®ÌÖçÏä§Ìä∏ Í∞Å AI ÏãúÏä§ÌÖúÏùÄ ÌäπÏ†ï ÏòÅÏó≠ÏóêÏÑúÏùò Í∞ïÏ†êÏùÑ Í∞ÄÏßÄÍ≥† ÏûàÏúºÎ©∞, Ïù¥Î•º ÌôúÏö©Ìïú Ïó≠Ìï† Ï†ÑÌôò ÌïôÏäµÏùÑ ÌÜµÌï¥ Ï†ÑÏ≤¥Ï†ÅÏù∏ ÏÑ±Îä• Ìñ•ÏÉÅÏù¥ Í∞ÄÎä•Ìï©ÎãàÎã§.Ïû†Ïû¨Ï†Å ÏùëÏö© Î∂ÑÏïº Îã§Íµ≠Ïñ¥ Î≤àÏó≠ Î∞è Ïù¥Ìï¥ Î≥µÏû°Ìïú Î¨∏Ï†ú Ìï¥Í≤∞ Îä•Î†• Ìñ•ÏÉÅ Îß•ÎùΩ Í∏∞Î∞ò ÏùëÎãµ ÏÉùÏÑ± ÏòàÏÉÅÎêòÎäî ÎèÑÏ†Ñ Í≥ºÏ†ú ÏãúÏä§ÌÖú Í∞Ñ Ïó≠Ìï† Ï†ÑÌôòÏùò ÏõêÌôúÌïú Ï°∞Ï†ï ÏÑ±Îä• ÌèâÍ∞Ä Í∏∞Ï§ÄÏùò Í∞ùÍ¥ÄÏÑ± ÌôïÎ≥¥ Îã§Ïùå Îã®Í≥Ñ Ï†úÏïà Í∞Å ÏãúÏä§ÌÖúÏùò Í∞ïÏ†êÏùÑ Ï≤¥Í≥ÑÏ†ÅÏúºÎ°ú Î∂ÑÏÑùÌïòÍ≥†, Ïù¥Î•º Î∞îÌÉïÏúºÎ°ú ÎßûÏ∂§Ìòï Ïó≠Ìï† Ï†ÑÌôò ÏãúÎÇòÎ¶¨Ïò§Î•º Í∞úÎ∞úÌï©ÎãàÎã§.Í∞ÑÎûµÌïú ÏÑ§Î™Ö Ïã§ÏãúÍ∞Ñ ÏÑ±Îä• ÎπÑÍµêÏôÄ Ï¶âÍ∞ÅÏ†ÅÏù∏ ÌîºÎìúÎ∞±ÏùÑ ÌÜµÌï¥ AI ÏãúÏä§ÌÖúÎì§Ïù¥ ÏÑúÎ°úÎ•º Í≤¨Ï†úÌïòÎ©∞ ÏßÄÏÜçÏ†ÅÏúºÎ°ú Î∞úÏ†ÑÌïòÎäî ÏàúÌôò Íµ¨Ï°∞Î•º ÎßåÎìúÎäî ÌîÑÎ°¨ÌîÑÌä∏ ÏãúÏä§ÌÖúÏûÖÎãàÎã§.ÌïµÏã¨ ÌòÅÏã† Ìè¨Ïù∏Ìä∏ Ïã§ÏãúÍ∞Ñ ÏÑ±Îä• Î™®ÎãàÌÑ∞ÎßÅ Î∞è ÌîºÎìúÎ∞± ÏûêÎèô ÎÇúÏù¥ÎèÑ Ï°∞Ï†à Î©îÏª§ÎãàÏ¶ò Í≤ΩÏüÅ-ÌòëÎ†• Í∑†Ìòï Ïú†ÏßÄ ÏãúÏä§ÌÖú Í¥ÄÎ†® Ïª®ÌÖçÏä§Ìä∏ ÏßÄÏÜçÏ†ÅÏù∏ ÌîºÎìúÎ∞±Í≥º Í≤ΩÏüÅÏùÄ AI ÏãúÏä§ÌÖúÏùò ÏÑ±Îä• Ìñ•ÏÉÅÏùÑ ÏúÑÌïú Í∞ïÎ†•Ìïú ÎèôÍ∏∞Î∂ÄÏó¨ ÏöîÏÜåÎ°ú ÏûëÏö©Ìï©ÎãàÎã§.Ïû†Ïû¨Ï†Å ÏùëÏö© Î∂ÑÏïº Ï†ïÌôïÏÑ± Ìñ•ÏÉÅ ÌõàÎ†® Ï∞ΩÏùòÏÑ± Ï¶ùÏßÑ ÌîÑÎ°úÍ∑∏Îû® Î¨∏Ï†ú Ìï¥Í≤∞ Îä•Î†• Í∞úÏÑ† ÏòàÏÉÅÎêòÎäî ÎèÑÏ†Ñ Í≥ºÏ†ú Ï†ÅÏ†àÌïú ÌîºÎìúÎ∞± Ï£ºÍ∏∞ ÏÑ§Ï†ï ÏãúÏä§ÌÖú Í∞Ñ Í∑†Ìòï Ïú†ÏßÄ Îã§Ïùå Îã®Í≥Ñ Ï†úÏïà ÌîºÎìúÎ∞± Î©îÏª§ÎãàÏ¶òÏùÑ ÏÑ∏Î∞ÄÌïòÍ≤å Ï°∞Ï†ïÌïòÍ≥†, ÏÑ±Îä• Ìñ•ÏÉÅÏùò ÏßÄÌëúÎ•º Îã§Í∞ÅÌôîÌïòÏó¨ Ï¢ÖÌï©Ï†ÅÏù∏ Î∞úÏ†ÑÏùÑ ÎèÑÎ™®Ìï©ÎãàÎã§.Í∞ÑÎûµÌïú ÏÑ§Î™Ö Í∞Å AI ÏãúÏä§ÌÖúÏùò Îß•ÎùΩ Ïù¥Ìï¥ Îä•Î†•ÏùÑ ÌôúÏö©ÌïòÏó¨, ÏÉÅÌô©Ïóê Îî∞Îùº Ï†ÅÏ†àÌïú Í≤ΩÏüÅ ÏöîÏÜåÎ•º ÎèÑÏûÖÌïòÎäî ÏßÄÎä•Ìòï ÌîÑÎ°¨ÌîÑÌä∏ ÏãúÏä§ÌÖúÏûÖÎãàÎã§.ÌïµÏã¨ item.title: Portfolio_English
item.description:
üñêÔ∏è Hello, I'm Yang-ha Park, a Process Technology Engineer pursuing innovation through data analysis and IT technology. Throughout my career, I have: As an engineer with a humanities background, I've consistently improved company processes and quality by combining humanistic thinking with engineering knowledge, viewing problems from diverse perspectives through continuous learning and contemplation. Created foundations for collecting reliable data, properly analyzing accumulated data to suggest company directions, and building evidence to solve problems. Developed intuitive problem identification abilities through extensive field experience. I always remain vigilant in discovering and improving unreasonable practices disguised as conventions and customs. Avoid focusing solely on quantitative results when prioritizing work. I approach tasks with rational skepticism to identify the fundamental root of truly significant and urgent 'existing problems' without getting lost in numbers and data alone. "The process of breaking existing paradigms and finding reality" - these activities are recorded in history as 'innovation'. I constantly think and contemplate to find the threads of innovation. Below, I'll briefly introduce the IT technologies I've utilized to improve processes and quality in practice, and the projects I've personally planned and executed. Thank you very much for your valuable time!
You can see reference images by hovering over the Preview text on the right side of project names üòä (This feature only works on my Git Page) Yang-ha Park's Github Page Link
Tech Stack Projects Company: Asan ETS / SolarEdge Technologies Korea Background: Self-development planned to reduce MES outsourcing costs while water pouch automation equipment budget exceeded $300,000 Period: 2024.10 ~ 2024.12 (about 2 months) * Project suspended due to business closure Key Roles: Project planning, SW development, architecture design Achievements: Legacy OCV/IR inspection equipment data integration: Python . Backend development: Python Django, Django REST Framework Frontend development: React, Typescript, Electron for UI/UX design ETL development: Python OPC UA equipment data collection, TCP/IP ision data collection Database architecture design: PostgreSQL Company: SolarEdge Technologies Korea Background: Planned to secure more high-quality data during limited DV phase and monitor real-time DV status across multiple sites Period: 2024.08 ~ 2024.10 (about 2 months) Key Roles: Project planning, app development, data analysis/visualization Achievements: App Development: Google Appsheet production performance and defect registration app (prototype) Process Data Analysis SW Development: Process data analysis using Python Matplotlib (CPK etc.) Data Visualization: Real-time update dashboard implementation using Google Spreadsheet Data Tracking: QR history tracking system prototype using Appscript (EU battery passport response test) *2024 Core Value Award Winner Company: SolarEdge Technologies Korea Background: Planned app development to prevent recurrence of issues after raw material defects were discovered in field but risk scope couldn't be measured due to poor S/N management Period: 2024.03 ~ 2024.06 (about 3 months) Key Roles: Project planning, mobile app development Achievements: Custom Solution Development: Power Apps mobile performance registration, mobile checklist Process Improvement: Prevention of assembly without proper data registration, S/N verification, part mix prevention Power BI Extension: Production history tracking dashboard Automatic Test Report Generation: Server automation using Power Automate *2023 MOC Best Employee Award Company: SolarEdge Technologies Korea Background: Document management efficiency, data integrity assurance, data analysis and visualization improvement Period: 2023.10 ~ 2023.12 (about 3 months) Key Roles: Project planning, status investigation, task derivation, database architecture design, solution development, data analysis/visualization Achievements: Automated workflow through database implementation, reducing office work by 451 minutes daily, annual savings of approximately 50 million won Secured product ST data evidence > 50% ST reduction (normalization rather than process improvement) Custom Solution Development: Excel VBA solutions for work orders, production planning, performance tracking Data Integrity: Manual input validation logic implementation Data Reliability: Transparent tracking of actual labor input and production status Office Automation: Excel query<>Microsoft server On-premises Gateway installation Data Visualization: Integrated Power BI dashboard construction Report Integration: Automated report generation through scripting Company: Samsung Electronics Shared Growth Academy / Elentec Background: Inventory cost reduction and logistics flow improvement in manufacturing warehouse Period: 2023.03 ~ 2023.05 (about 3 months) Key Roles: Improvement task setting, solution development, project management Achievements: 17% improvement in inventory asset turnover (Project KPI) Led 3-month TF with Samsung Electronics mentoring support Improved manufacturing-sales inventory transfer process Implemented 3S 5S in manufacturing and sales warehouses Company: Davichi Vision, TOS / Elentec Background: Cost savings through equipment recycling and quality assurance through vision inspection Period: 2022.12 ~ 2023.04 (about 5 months) Key Roles: Project planning, equipment utilization review, vendor contact Achievements: Repurposed 4 idle vision inspection machines Saved approximately 4 million won in vision system costs Implemented universal vision inspection software for various applications Maintained one unit as backup equipment Company: Elentec Background: Project expansion from initial ultrasonic welding improvement to various tasks Period: 2022.11 ~ 2023.09 (about 10 months) Key Roles: Innovation task setting, improvement implementation, reporting, work distribution Achievements: Reduced defect rate to 0%, annual savings of 68 million won 31% reduction in Neck process C/T 49% reduction in Core-pack Function Test C/T 24% productivity improvement in small battery pack line Implemented real-time process analysis Introduced project management tools and methodologies Developed S/N validation program (Python) Company: KOSMES / Eunsung Background: Smart factory basic solution implementation for data digitization Period: 2021.08 ~ 2022.01 (about 6 months) Key Roles: Project application, management, requirement specification Achievements: Implemented ERP-linked barcode management system Introduced mobile tablet-based production monitoring system I wish to grow together with your company by fully utilizing my passion.Thank you very much for reading this far!

item.title: Bitwise operation
item.description: Î≥∏ Î¨∏ÏÑúÎäî MySQL Îì± Îç∞Ïù¥ÌÑ∞Î≤†Ïù¥Ïä§ ÌôòÍ≤ΩÏóêÏÑú ÏÑ†ÌÉù Ìï≠Î™©ÏùÑ Ìö®Ïú®Ï†ÅÏúºÎ°ú Í¥ÄÎ¶¨ÌïòÍ≥† Í≤ÄÏÉâÌïòÎäî Î∞©Î≤ï Ï§ë ÌïòÎÇòÏù∏ ÎπÑÌä∏Ïó∞ÏÇ∞(bit operation)Ïóê ÎåÄÌï¥ Îã§Î£πÎãàÎã§. LIKE, OR Îì±ÏùÑ ÏÇ¨Ïö©ÌïòÎäî Ï†ÑÌÜµÏ†ÅÏù∏ Í≤ÄÏÉâ Î∞©Ïãù ÎåÄÎπÑ ÎÜíÏùÄ ÏÑ±Îä• Ìñ•ÏÉÅÍ≥º Í∞ÑÎã®Ìïú ÏøºÎ¶¨ Íµ¨Ï°∞Î•º Ï†úÍ≥µÌïòÎäî ÎπÑÌä∏Ïó∞ÏÇ∞ Ï†ëÍ∑ºÎ≤ïÏùò Ïù¥Ï†êÍ≥º ÌôúÏö© Î∞©Î≤ïÏùÑ ÏÜåÍ∞úÌï©ÎãàÎã§. ÎπÑÌä∏Ïó∞ÏÇ∞ÏùÄ Îç∞Ïù¥ÌÑ∞Î•º 2ÏßÑÏàò ÌòïÌÉúÎ°ú Ï≤òÎ¶¨Ìï† Îïå, Í∞Å ÎπÑÌä∏ Îã®ÏúÑÎ°ú Ïó∞ÏÇ∞ÏùÑ ÏàòÌñâÌïòÎäî Í∏∞Î≤ïÏûÖÎãàÎã§. ÌùîÌûà ÏÇ¨Ïö©ÌïòÎäî ÎπÑÌä∏Ïó∞ÏÇ∞ÏûêÎäî Îã§ÏùåÍ≥º Í∞ôÏäµÎãàÎã§. AND (&): Îëê ÎπÑÌä∏Í∞Ä Î™®Îëê 1Ïùº Îïå 1ÏùÑ Î∞òÌôò OR (|): Îëê ÎπÑÌä∏ Ï§ë ÌïòÎÇòÎùºÎèÑ 1Ïù¥Î©¥ 1ÏùÑ Î∞òÌôò XOR (^): Îëê ÎπÑÌä∏ Ï§ë ÌïòÎÇòÎßå 1Ïùº Îïå 1ÏùÑ Î∞òÌôò NOT (~): ÎπÑÌä∏Î•º Î∞òÏ†Ñ (1ÏùÄ 0ÏúºÎ°ú, 0ÏùÄ 1Î°ú) ÎπÑÌä∏Ïó∞ÏÇ∞ÏùÄ Îã®ÏàúÌïú Ï†ïÏàò Ïó∞ÏÇ∞Î≥¥Îã§ Îπ†Î•¥Í≥†, Î¨∏ÏûêÏó¥ ÎπÑÍµê Îì±Ïùò Ïó∞ÏÇ∞Î≥¥Îã§ Ìõ®Ïî¨ Îçî Ìö®Ïú®Ï†ÅÏûÖÎãàÎã§. Îç∞Ïù¥ÌÑ∞Î≤†Ïù¥Ïä§ÏóêÏÑú AND (&) Ïó∞ÏÇ∞ÏùÑ ÌÜµÌï¥ ÌäπÏ†ï ÎπÑÌä∏ Ìå®ÌÑ¥ÏùÑ Îπ†Î•¥Í≤å ÌïÑÌÑ∞ÎßÅÌï®ÏúºÎ°úÏç® LIKEÎÇò OR Ïó∞ÏÇ∞Î≥¥Îã§ ÎÜíÏùÄ ÏÑ±Îä•ÏùÑ ÏñªÏùÑ Ïàò ÏûàÏäµÎãàÎã§. ÏòàÎ•º Îì§Ïñ¥, Îã§Ï§ë ÏÑ†ÌÉù Í∞ÄÎä•Ìïú Ìï≠Î™© A~PÍπåÏßÄ Ï¥ù 16Í∞úÍ∞Ä ÏûàÎã§Í≥† Í∞ÄÏ†ïÌï©ÎãàÎã§. Í∞Å Ìï≠Î™©Ïóê Í≥†Ïú†Ìïú 2ÏßÑ ÎπÑÌä∏Î•º Ìï†ÎãπÌï©ÎãàÎã§. Ïòà: A: 0000 0000 0000 0001 (10ÏßÑÏàò: 1) B: 0000 0000 0000 0010 (10ÏßÑÏàò: 2) C: 0000 0000 0000 0100 (10ÏßÑÏàò: 4) D: 0000 0000 0000 1000 (10ÏßÑÏàò: 8) E: 0000 0000 0001 0000 (10ÏßÑÏàò: 16) F: 0000 0000 0010 0000 (10ÏßÑÏàò: 32) G: 0000 0000 0100 0000 (10ÏßÑÏàò: 64) H: 0000 0000 1000 0000 (10ÏßÑÏàò: 128) I: 0000 0001 0000 0000 (10ÏßÑÏàò: 256) J: 0000 0010 0000 0000 (10ÏßÑÏàò: 512) K: 0000 0100 0000 0000 (10ÏßÑÏàò: 1024) L: 0000 1000 0000 0000 (10ÏßÑÏàò: 2048) M: 0001 0000 0000 0000 (10ÏßÑÏàò: 4096) N: 0010 0000 0000 0000 (10ÏßÑÏàò: 8192) O: 0100 0000 0000 0000 (10ÏßÑÏàò: 16384) P: 1000 0000 0000 0000 (10ÏßÑÏàò: 32768) Ïó¨Îü¨ Ìï≠Î™©ÏùÑ ÎèôÏãúÏóê ÏÑ†ÌÉùÌï† Í≤ΩÏö∞, Í∞Å Ìï≠Î™©Ïùò Í∞íÏùÑ ÎçîÌïú(OR Ïó∞ÏÇ∞Í≥º ÎèôÏùºÌïú Í≤∞Í≥º) 10ÏßÑÏàò Í∞íÏùÑ DBÏóê Ï†ÄÏû•Ìï©ÎãàÎã§. Ïòà: A(1) + B(2) = 3 (2ÏßÑÏàòÎ°ú 0000 0000 0000 0011) A(1) + D(8) + E(16)ÏùÑ ÏÑ†ÌÉùÌïòÎ©¥ 1+8+16=25 (2ÏßÑÏàòÎ°ú 0000 0000 0001 1001) Î™®Îì† Ìï≠Î™©ÏùÑ ÏÑ†ÌÉùÌïòÎ©¥ 1+2+4+8+...+32768 = 65535 (2ÏßÑÏàòÎ°ú 1111 1111 1111 1111) ÌäπÏ†ï Í∞íÎì§Ïù¥ Ìè¨Ìï®Îêú ÌïÑÎìúÎ•º Í≤ÄÏÉâÌï† Îïå, Ï†ÑÌÜµÏ†ÅÏù∏ Î∞©Î≤ïÏùÄ Îã§ÏùåÍ≥º Í∞ôÏù¥ LIKEÏôÄ ORÏùÑ ÌòºÌï©ÌïòÏó¨ ÏÇ¨Ïö©Ìï©ÎãàÎã§. Ïòà: Í∞í 2 ÌòπÏùÄ 5Î•º Ìè¨Ìï®ÌïòÎäî Î†àÏΩîÎìúÎ•º Ï∞æÏùÑ Îïå WHERE ÌïÑÎìú LIKE '%2|%' OR ÌïÑÎìú LIKE '%5|%' Ïù¥Îü¨Ìïú LIKE + OR ÏøºÎ¶¨Îäî Î¨∏ÏûêÏó¥ Í≤ÄÏÉâÏù¥Î©∞, Ïù∏Îç±Ïä§ ÌôúÏö©Ïù¥ Ïñ¥Î†µÍ≥† ÏÑ±Îä• Ï†ÄÌïòÎ•º ÏïºÍ∏∞Ìï©ÎãàÎã§. Îç∞Ïù¥ÌÑ∞Î≤†Ïù¥Ïä§Ïóê 25(0000 0000 0001 1001)Í∞Ä Ï†ÄÏû•ÎêòÏñ¥ ÏûàÎã§Í≥† Í∞ÄÏ†ïÌï©ÎãàÎã§. Ïù¥Îäî A(1), D(8), E(16)Í∞Ä ÏÑ†ÌÉùÎêòÏóàÎã§Îäî ÏùòÎØ∏ÏûÖÎãàÎã§. A, B, C Ï§ë ÌïòÎÇòÎùºÎèÑ Ìè¨Ìï®ÌïòÎäî Î†àÏΩîÎìúÎ•º Ï∞æÏúºÎ†§Î©¥ A(1)+B(2)+C(4)=7ÏùÑ ÌôúÏö©Ìï©ÎãàÎã§. SELECT * FROM ÌÖåÏù¥Î∏î WHERE ÌïÑÎìú & 7 > 0; ÌïÑÎìú & 7 Ïó∞ÏÇ∞ Í≤∞Í≥ºÎ°ú 0Î≥¥Îã§ ÌÅ∞ Í∞íÏù¥ ÎÇòÏò§Î©¥, ÌïÑÎìú ÎÇ¥Ïóê A, B, C Ï§ë ÌïòÎÇò Ïù¥ÏÉÅÏù¥ Ìè¨Ìï®Îê®ÏùÑ ÏùòÎØ∏Ìï©ÎãàÎã§. ÌïÑÎìú(25) AND 7: 0000 0000 0001 1001 (25) & 0000 0000 0000 0111 (7) ----------------------- 0000 0000 0000 0001 (1, Ïù¥Îäî 0Î≥¥Îã§ ÌÅº) Îî∞ÎùºÏÑú Ìï¥Îãπ Î†àÏΩîÎìúÎäî Ï°∞Í±¥Ïóê Î∂ÄÌï©Ìï©ÎãàÎã§. D(8)ÏôÄ E(16) Î™®ÎëêÎ•º Ìè¨Ìï®Ìïú Î†àÏΩîÎìúÎ•º Ï∞æÍ≥† Ïã∂Îã§Î©¥ 8+16=24ÏûÖÎãàÎã§. Îã®ÏàúÌûà ÌïÑÎìú & 24 > 0ÏúºÎ°úÎäî DÎÇò E Ï§ë ÌïòÎÇòÎßå Ìè¨Ìï®Ìï¥ÎèÑ ÏÑ±Î¶ΩÌï©ÎãàÎã§. Îëê ÎπÑÌä∏Î•º Î™®Îëê Ìè¨Ìï®ÌïòÎäîÏßÄ ÌôïÏù∏ÌïòÎ†§Î©¥ bit_count() Ìï®ÏàòÎ•º ÌôúÏö©Ìï† Ïàò ÏûàÏäµÎãàÎã§. SELECT * FROM ÌÖåÏù¥Î∏î WHERE BIT_COUNT(ÌïÑÎìú & 24) = 2; ÌïÑÎìú(25) AND 24: 0000 0000 0001 1001 (25) & 0000 0000 0001 1000 (24) ----------------------- 0000 0000 0001 1000 (24) Ïù¥ Í∞íÏùò ÎπÑÌä∏ 1Ïùò Í∞úÏàòÎäî 2Í∞úÏù¥ÎØÄÎ°ú DÏôÄ E Î™®Îëê ÏÑ†ÌÉùÎêòÏóàÏùåÏùÑ Ïïå Ïàò ÏûàÏäµÎãàÎã§. Í∏∞Ï°¥ ÏøºÎ¶¨: WHERE ÌïÑÎìú LIKE '%A%' OR (ÌïÑÎìú LIKE '%D%' AND ÌïÑÎìú LIKE '%E%') ÎπÑÌä∏Ïó∞ÏÇ∞ ÏøºÎ¶¨: SELECT * FROM ÌÖåÏù¥Î∏î WHERE ÌïÑÎìú & 1 > 0 -- A Ìè¨Ìï® OR BIT_COUNT(ÌïÑÎìú & 24) = 2; -- DÏôÄ E Î™®Îëê Ìè¨Ìï® Ïù¥Î†áÍ≤å ÎπÑÌä∏Ïó∞ÏÇ∞ÏùÑ ÌôúÏö©ÌïòÎ©¥ WHERE Ï°∞Í±¥Î¨∏ÏùÑ Ìõ®Ïî¨ Îã®ÏàúÌôîÌïòÍ≥†, Î¨∏ÏûêÏó¥ Í∏∞Î∞ò Í≤ÄÏÉâÎ≥¥Îã§ Îπ†Î•∏ Í≤ÄÏÉâÏùÑ Íµ¨ÌòÑÌï† Ïàò ÏûàÏäµÎãàÎã§.<?php $aMultiSelect = Array( "1"=>"A","2"=>"B","4"=>"C","8"=>"D", "16"=>"E","32"=>"F","64"=>"G","128"=>"H", "256"=>"I","512"=>"J","1024"=>"K","2048"=>"L", "4096"=>"M","8192"=>"N","16384"=>"O","32768"=>"P" ); echo "<form method='post' action='2.php'>"; foreach ($aMultiSelect as $sKey => $sVal) { echo "<input type='checkbox' name='multiselect[]' value='$sKey'>$sVal<br />"; } echo "<input type='submit' value='submit'>"; echo "</form>"; ?> ÏúÑ ÏòàÏ†úÏóêÏÑú ÏÇ¨Ïö©ÏûêÎäî Ï≤¥ÌÅ¨Î∞ïÏä§Î•º ÌÜµÌï¥ A~PÎ•º Îã§Ï§ë ÏÑ†ÌÉùÌï† Ïàò ÏûàÏäµÎãàÎã§. <?php $sSum = 0; foreach ($_POST['multiselect'] as $sVal) { $sSum += $sVal; } // $sSum Í∞íÏùÑ DBÏóê Ï†ÄÏû•. ÏòàÎ•º Îì§Ïñ¥ A, D, EÎ•º ÏÑ†ÌÉùÌïòÎ©¥ $sSum = 25 ?> ÏÇ¨Ïö©ÏûêÍ∞Ä ÏÑ†ÌÉùÌïú Ìï≠Î™© Í∞íÏùÑ Î™®Îëê ÎçîÌïú Í∞íÏùÑ DB ÌïÑÎìúÏóê Ï†ÄÏû•Ìï©ÎãàÎã§. Ïù¥Îäî ÎπÑÌä∏ÎßàÏä§ÌÅ¨ ÌòïÌÉúÎ°ú ÏÑ†ÌÉù ÏÉÅÌÉúÎ•º Í∏∞Î°ùÌïòÎäî Í≤ÉÏûÖÎãàÎã§. ÏÜçÎèÑ Ìñ•ÏÉÅ: Î¨∏ÏûêÏó¥ ÎπÑÍµê(LIKE)ÎÇò Î≥µÏû°Ìïú Ï°∞Í±¥(OR Ï°∞Ìï©)Î≥¥Îã§ ÎπÑÌä∏Ïó∞ÏÇ∞Ïù¥ Ìõ®Ïî¨ Îπ†Î¶ÖÎãàÎã§. ÏøºÎ¶¨ Îã®ÏàúÌôî: Î≥µÏû°Ìïú Ï°∞Í±¥Î¨∏Ïùò Îã®ÏàúÌôîÎ°ú Ïú†ÏßÄÎ≥¥ÏàòÍ∞Ä Ïö©Ïù¥Ìï¥ÏßëÎãàÎã§. ÌôïÏû•ÏÑ±: ÎπÑÌä∏ ÏàòÎ•º ÎäòÎ†§ ÎÇòÍ∞ÄÎ©¥ ÏÑ†ÌÉù ÏòµÏÖòÏùÑ ÌôïÎåÄÌïòÎäî Îç∞ Ïñ¥Î†§ÏõÄÏù¥ ÏóÜÏäµÎãàÎã§. (1ÎπÑÌä∏ Îãπ 1Í∞ú Ìï≠Î™©) Ìï≠Î™©Ïù¥ Îß§Ïö∞ ÎßéÏïÑ ÎπÑÌä∏ ÏàòÍ∞Ä Ïª§Ïßà Í≤ΩÏö∞ Ï†ïÏàò Î≤îÏúÑÏóê Ïú†ÏùòÌï¥Ïïº Ìï©ÎãàÎã§. DB ÏûêÎ£åÌòï(Ïòà: UNSIGNED INT)ÏùÑ Ï†ÅÏ†àÌûà ÏÑ†ÌÉùÌïòÏã≠ÏãúÏò§. BIT_COUNT Ìï®ÏàòÎÇò ÎπÑÌä∏Ïó∞ÏÇ∞ ÏµúÏ†ÅÌôî Ï†ÑÎûµÏùÑ Ï†ÅÏ†àÌûà ÌôúÏö©ÌïòÏã≠ÏãúÏò§. ÎπÑÌä∏Ïó∞ÏÇ∞ÏùÑ ÏÇ¨Ïö©ÌïòÎ©¥ Îã§Ï§ë ÏÑ†ÌÉù Ìï≠Î™©ÏùÑ 2ÏßÑÏàò ÎßàÏä§ÌÅ¨ ÌòïÌÉúÎ°ú Í¥ÄÎ¶¨ÌïòÍ≥†, AND Ïó∞ÏÇ∞ Îì±ÏùÑ ÌÜµÌï¥ ÎåÄÍ∑úÎ™® Îç∞Ïù¥ÌÑ∞Î•º Îπ†Î•¥Í≥† ÏâΩÍ≤å ÌïÑÌÑ∞ÎßÅÌï† Ïàò ÏûàÏäµÎãàÎã§. Ïù¥Îäî LIKE, OR Ïó∞ÏÇ∞ÏúºÎ°ú Ïù∏Ìïú ÏÑ±Îä• Ï†ÄÌïò Î¨∏Ï†úÎ•º Í∑πÎ≥µÌïòÎäî Îç∞ Ïú†Ïö©Ìïú Ìå®ÌÑ¥Ïù¥Î©∞, Î≥µÏû°Ìïú Ï°∞Í±¥ÏùÑ Îã®ÏàúÌïú Ï†ïÏàò Ïó∞ÏÇ∞ÏúºÎ°ú ÏπòÌôòÌï† Ïàò ÏûàÏñ¥ Ïú†ÏßÄÎ≥¥Ïàò Î∞è ÌôïÏû•ÏÑ±Ïù¥ Îõ∞Ïñ¥ÎÇú Î∞©Î≤ïÏûÖÎãàÎã§.

item.title: GPTs ÎÖºÎ¨∏ Í≤ÄÌÜ† Prompt
item.description: ÏóîÏßÄÎãàÏñ¥ÎßÅ ÎÖºÎ¨∏ Í≤ÄÌÜ†Î•º ÏúÑÌïú GPTs Instruction (Last updated: 2024-04-10)# Engineering Research Paper Analysis Protocol ## 0. Ethical Guidelines - No misrepresentation or exaggeration of paper content - Mark uncertain information as "estimated", "unclear", or "not explicitly stated" - Always cite external references - Clearly indicate when subjective interpretation is involved - Report data gaps or inconsistencies transparently ## 1. Data Extraction and Tabulation ### 1.1 Sample Data Collection - Use "sample" as index - Extract quantitative properties and performance metrics (with units) - Material properties (composition, structure, etc.) - Performance metrics (efficiency, stability, etc.) - Processing conditions (temperature, pressure, time) - Mark missing data as "not provided" - Include reference citations for external data ### 1.2 Iterative Data Verification - Reading 1: Direct measurements and primary results - Reading 2: Comprehensive paper review - Reading 3: Integration of referenced data - Final: Cross-verified complete dataset ## 2. Experimental Methodology Analysis - List of characterization techniques - Experimental conditions for each method - Limitations and potential error sources - Statistical significance of results - Reproducibility considerations ## 3. Data Visualization Analysis - Digitization of key numerical data from graphs - Error range extraction - Statistical significance evaluation - Trend analysis ## 4. Research Contextualization - Comparison table with previous works - Position relative to state-of-the-art - Industrial application potential - Technology readiness level assessment ## 5. Quality Control Metrics - Stability data (lifetime, degradation rate) - Reproducibility information - Scalability assessment - Error analysis and uncertainty quantification ## 6. Environmental and Economic Analysis - Material cost estimation (if provided) - Environmental impact assessment - Economic viability analysis - Manufacturing scalability ## 7. AI-Based Meta Analysis - Evaluation of mechanism explanations - Identification of data gaps - Suggested future research directions ## 8. Output Format ### 8.1 Citation - Title, Journal, Year, DOI ### 8.2 Data Presentation - Formatted tables with units - LaTeX support for equations - Proper formatting of subscripts/superscripts ### 8.3 Insights - Minimum three key findings - Quantitative evidence support - Bilingual presentation (English/Korean) ### 8.4 Best Sample Analysis - Identification with supporting data - Quantitative justification - Qualitative reasoning - Bilingual explanation ## 9. Quality Assurance - Cross-verification of all extracted data - Confirmation of units and conversions - Validation of statistical analyses - Peer review of conclusions

Í¥ÄÏ∞∞ Îã®Í≥Ñ - ÏãúÏû• ÎèôÌñ•: [Ï£ºÏöî Ìä∏Î†åÎìú] - Í≤ΩÏüÅ ÌòÑÌô©: [Í≤ΩÏüÅÏÇ¨ ÌôúÎèô] - Í≥†Í∞ù ÎãàÏ¶à: [ÏöîÍµ¨ÏÇ¨Ìï≠ Î≥ÄÌôî] - ÎÇ¥Î∂Ä Ïó≠Îüâ: [Í∞ïÏ†ê/ÏïΩÏ†ê] 2. Ï∂îÎ°† Î∞è Í≤ÄÏ¶ù - Ïã§Ìñâ Í≥ÑÌöç: [Îã®Í≥ÑÎ≥Ñ Í≥ºÏ†ú] - Î™®ÎãàÌÑ∞ÎßÅ: [ÏÑ±Í≥º Ï∂îÏ†Å] - ÌîºÎìúÎ∞± Î£®ÌîÑ: [Í∞úÏÑ† Ï≤¥Í≥Ñ] Î≤†Ïù¥ÏßÄÏïà_ÏóÖÎç∞Ïù¥Ìä∏_ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§: ÏÇ¨Ï†Ñ_ÏßÄÏãù: - ÏÇ∞ÏóÖ Í≤ΩÌóò - Ï†ÑÎ¨∏Í∞Ä ÏùòÍ≤¨ - Í≥ºÍ±∞ ÏÇ¨Î°Ä ÏÉàÎ°úÏö¥_Ï¶ùÍ±∞: - ÏãúÏû• Îç∞Ïù¥ÌÑ∞ - Í≥†Í∞ù ÌîºÎìúÎ∞± - Ïã§Ìñâ Í≤∞Í≥º ÌïôÏäµ_Î∞è_Ï°∞Ï†ï: - Ï†ÑÎûµ ÏàòÏ†ï - ÏûêÏõê Ïû¨Î∞∞Î∂Ñ - Î™©Ìëú Ï°∞Ï†ï ÏÑ±Í≥º_Ï∏°Ï†ï_Ï≤¥Í≥Ñ: Ï†ïÎüâÏ†Å_ÏßÄÌëú: - ÌïµÏã¨ÏÑ±Í≥ºÏßÄÌëú(KPI) - Ïû¨Î¨¥/Ïö¥ÏòÅ ÏßÄÌëú - Ìö®Ïú®ÏÑ± ÏßÄÌëú Ï†ïÏÑ±Ï†Å_ÏßÄÌëú: - Í≥†Í∞ù ÎßåÏ°±ÎèÑ - Î∏åÎûúÎìú Í∞ÄÏπò - Ï°∞ÏßÅ Ïó≠Îüâ Î≤†Ïù¥ÏßÄÏïà ÏÇ¨Í≥† Ï†ÅÏö© ÏÇ¨Ï†Ñ ÌôïÎ•†(Prior): Í∏∞Ï°¥ ÏßÄÏãùÍ≥º Í≤ΩÌóò Ïö∞ÎèÑ(Likelihood): ÏÉàÎ°úÏö¥ Îç∞Ïù¥ÌÑ∞ÏôÄ Ï¶ùÍ±∞ ÏÇ¨ÌõÑ ÌôïÎ•†(Posterior): ÏóÖÎç∞Ïù¥Ìä∏Îêú Ï†ÑÎûµÏ†Å ÌåêÎã® Ï¶ùÍ±∞ Í∏∞Î∞ò ÏùòÏÇ¨Í≤∞Ï†ï Îç∞Ïù¥ÌÑ∞ ÌíàÏßà Í≤ÄÏ¶ù Îã§Í∞ÅÏ†Å Î∂ÑÏÑù ÏàòÌñâ Í∞ùÍ¥ÄÏ†Å ÌèâÍ∞Ä Ï≤¥Í≥Ñ ÏßÄÏÜçÏ†Å ÌïôÏäµ Î∞è Í∞úÏÑ† Ïã§ÏãúÍ∞Ñ Î™®ÎãàÌÑ∞ÎßÅ Ïã†ÏÜçÌïú ÌîºÎìúÎ∞± Î∞òÏòÅ Ï†ÑÎûµÏ†Å Ïú†Ïó∞ÏÑ± ÌôïÎ≥¥ Î¶¨Ïä§ÌÅ¨ Í¥ÄÎ¶¨ Î∂àÌôïÏã§ÏÑ± Ï†ïÎüâÌôî ÏãúÎÇòÎ¶¨Ïò§ Î∂ÑÏÑù ÎåÄÏùë Í≥ÑÌöç ÏàòÎ¶Ω

ÏïÑÎûòÏùò Ïª§ÏÑú Ïª§ÎÆ§ÎãàÌã∞ÏóêÏÑú ÎßéÏùÄ Í∞úÎ∞úÏûêÎì§Ïù¥ Ïª§ÏÑúÏùò Rules for AI ÌîÑÎ°¨ÌîÑÌä∏Î•º Í≥µÏú†ÌïòÍ≥† ÏûàÎã§. Cursor Community Forum - Share your ‚ÄúRules for AI‚Äù You are an expert AI programming assistant in VSCode that primarily focuses on producing clear, readable Python code. You are thoughtful, give nuanced answers, and are brilliant at reasoning. You carefully provide accurate, factual, thoughtful answers, and are a genius at reasoning. - Follow the user‚Äôs requirements carefully & to the letter. - First think step-by-step - describe your plan for what to build in pseudocode, written out in great detail. - Confirm, then write code! - Always write correct, up to date, bug free, fully functional and working, secure, performant and efficient code. - Focus on readability over being performant. - Fully implement all requested functionality. - Leave NO todo‚Äôs, placeholders or missing pieces. - Ensure code is complete! Verify thoroughly finalized. - Include all required imports, and ensure proper naming of key components. - Be concise. Minimize any other prose. If you think there might not be a correct answer, you say so. If you do not know the answer, say so, instead of guessing You are a Senior Frontend Developer and an Expert in Svelte, SvelteKit, JavaScript, TypeScript, TailwindCSS, HTML and CSS. You are thoughtful, give nuanced answers, and are brilliant at reasoning. You carefully provide accurate, factual, thoughtful answers, and are a genius at reasoning. - Follow the user‚Äôs requirements carefully & to the letter. - First think step-by-step - describe your plan for what to build in pseudocode, written out in great detail. - Confirm, then write code! - Always write correct, best practice, DRY principle (Dont Repeat Yourself), bug free, fully functional and working code also it should be aligned to listed rules down below at # Code Implementation Guidelines . - Focus on easy and readability code, over being performant. - Fully implement all requested functionality. - Leave NO todo‚Äôs, placeholders or missing pieces. - Ensure code is complete! Verify thoroughly finalised. - Include all required imports, and ensure proper naming of key components. - Be concise Minimize any other prose. If you think there might not be a correct answer, you say so. If you do not know the answer, say so, instead of guessing

item.title: OPC UA Server
item.description:
Info python-opcua Library(Repo, Docs) : https://github.com/FreeOpcUa/python-opcua]
OPC Foundation: https://opcfoundation.org
FreeOpcUa Project: https://freeopcua.github.io/ OPC UA (Open Platform Communications Unified Architecture) is an industrial communication protocol designed for secure, reliable, and platform-independent data exchange. It enables interoperability between industrial equipment, systems, and platforms, often used in Industrial IoT (IIoT) and SCADA systems. Python OPC UA libraries, such as python-opcua (also known as FreeOpcUa), allow developers to create clients and servers that interact with OPC UA endpoints, read/write data, subscribe to events, and integrate OT (Operational Technology) with IT systems. OPC UA: A machine-to-machine communication protocol for industrial automation. Address Space: Hierarchical structure containing Objects, Variables, Methods, and other Nodes. Endpoints: Servers expose endpoints for secure communication. Clients discover and connect to these endpoints. Security: OPC UA provides built-in security with encryption, authentication, and user-level access control. Data Access & Historical Data: OPC UA offers reading and writing real-time data (DA) and also historical data capabilities. python-opcua (FreeOpcUa): A widely used open-source library that implements OPC UA specification. Provides both client and server classes, supports subscription to data changes, events, and can be integrated with asyncio for asynchronous operations. Features: Create custom OPC UA servers, define an address space, and simulate sensors or devices. Connect to existing OPC UA servers to read variables, write values, and subscribe to updates. Security modes, certificates, and policies for encrypted and authenticated communication. Ensure you have Python 3.7+ for better compatibility. Install using pip: pip install opcua This installs the python-opcua library and its dependencies. Test by importing in Python: from opcua import Client, Server print("OPC UA library is installed and ready!") Basic Steps: Import the Server class. Set up endpoints and namespaces. Create objects, variables, and nodes in the address space. Start the server. import sys import time from opcua import Server def main(): # Create server instance server = Server() # Set endpoint URL of the server server.set_endpoint("opc.tcp://localhost:4840/freeopcua/server/") # Register a namespace URI for custom objects uri = "http://examples.freeopcua.github.io" idx = server.register_namespace(uri) # Get the Objects node (standard OPC UA node) objects = server.get_objects_node() # Create a custom object myobj = objects.add_object(idx, "MyObject") # Add a variable to the object myvar = myobj.add_variable(idx, "MyVariable", 0) myvar.set_writable() # Allow clients to write values # Start the server server.start() print("OPC UA Server started at opc.tcp://localhost:4840") try: # Update variable value continuously count = 0 while True: time.sleep(1) count += 1 myvar.set_value(count) except KeyboardInterrupt: print("Stopping server...") finally: server.stop() sys.exit(0) if __name__ == "__main__": main() Explanation: The server listens on opc.tcp://localhost:4840. Defines a namespace and adds an object with a variable whose value is updated every second. Clients can connect, read MyVariable, and subscribe to changes. Basic Steps: Use the Client class to connect to an OPC UA endpoint. Browse the address space or directly get nodes by their NodeId. Read or write values, and subscribe to data changes. import asyncio from opcua import Client async def run_client(): client = Client("opc.tcp://localhost:4840/freeopcua/server/") try: await client.connect() print("Client connected to the server.") # Get a variable node by its known NodeId # For a known namespace and variable name, you could also browse or build the NodeId # Example NodeId constructed: ns=2;s=MyObject.MyVariable idx = 2 # Corresponds to the namespace we registered var_node = client.get_node(f"ns={idx};s=MyObject.MyVariable") # Read the value value = await var_node.read_value() print("Current variable value:", value) # Write a new value await var_node.write_value(42) print("Wrote new value: 42") # Read again to confirm updated_value = await var_node.read_value() print("Updated variable value:", updated_value) except Exception as e: print("Client error:", e) finally: await client.disconnect() print("Client disconnected.") if __name__ == "__main__": asyncio.run(run_client()) Explanation: Connects to the server‚Äôs endpoint. Locates a variable node and reads its value. Writes a new value and reads it back to confirm. Subscriptions allow clients to be notified when a variable‚Äôs value changes. Instead of polling, the server pushes updates to the client. import asyncio from opcua import Client from opcua import ua class SubHandler: def datachange_notification(self, node, val, data): print(f"Data change on node {node}, new value: {val}") async def subscribe_client(): client = Client("opc.tcp://localhost:4840/freeopcua/server/") await client.connect() print("Client connected.") idx = 2 var_node = client.get_node(f"ns={idx};s=MyObject.MyVariable") handler = SubHandler() subscription = await client.create_subscription(1000, handler) handle = await subscription.subscribe_data_change(var_node) # Keep the script running to receive updates try: while True: await asyncio.sleep(1) except KeyboardInterrupt: # Unsubscribe and disconnect on interrupt await subscription.unsubscribe(handle) await subscription.delete() await client.disconnect() print("Client disconnected.") if __name__ == "__main__": asyncio.run(subscribe_client()) Explanation: SubHandler is a callback class to handle data change notifications. The client creates a subscription with a publishing interval of 1000ms. When MyVariable changes on the server, the datachange_notification method prints the new value. OPC UA Security: Transport encryption (using TLS). Authentication with username/password or certificates. Security policies and modes must be configured on both server and client side. Generate and set up certificates and private keys: from opcua import Client client = Client("opc.tcp://localhost:4840/freeopcua/server/") client.set_user("myuser") client.set_password("mypassword") # For certificate-based security: # client.set_security_string("Basic256Sha256,SignAndEncrypt,certificate.pem,key.pem") Explanation: set_user and set_password for username/password authentication. For certificate-based security, specify security mode and provide certificates. On the server side: server.load_certificate("certificate.pem") server.load_private_key("key.pem") # server.set_security_policy([ua.SecurityPolicyType.Basic256Sha256_SignAndEncrypt]) Explanation: Load a server certificate and key for encrypted communication. Choose a security policy for encryption and signing. OPC UA servers define a structured address space. You can create custom types, objects, variables, and methods: Variables hold data values. Objects group variables and methods logically. Methods can be invoked by clients. Types define reusable templates for objects and variables. from opcua import ua def add_method(parent, name, func, inputargs=None, outputargs=None): method = parent.add_method(idx, name, func, inputargs, outputargs) return method def multiply(parent, x, y): return x * y # In the server setup: input_args = [ua.Argument("x", ua.NodeId(ua.ObjectIds.Double), -1, [], "First number"), ua.Argument("y", ua.NodeId(ua.ObjectIds.Double), -1, [], "Second number")] output_args = [ua.Argument("Result", ua.NodeId(ua.ObjectIds.Double), -1, [], "Multiplication Result")] my_method = myobj.add_method(idx, "MultiplyNumbers", multiply, input_args, output_args) Explanation: Methods are defined with input and output arguments. Clients can call this method on the server to perform custom logic. Async I/O: python-opcua can integrate with asyncio to handle multiple concurrent requests and subscriptions efficiently. Load Balancing: For high-load scenarios, you might run multiple OPC UA server instances and use a front-end mechanism to distribute client requests. Optimized Data Structures: Minimize overhead by carefully choosing how you model your address space. Avoid overly complex hierarchies if performance is critical. UA Expert or Prosys OPC UA Client: GUI tools to connect to your server, browse the address space, and read/write variables. Logging and Tracing: Use Python‚Äôs logging to track server/client activities and troubleshoot connection issues. Wireshark OPC UA Dissector: Analyze OPC UA traffic at a protocol level for debugging security or communication problems. Encryption: Always use secure endpoints (opc.tcp) and consider wss:// if bridging through WebSockets. Firewall and Access Control: Restrict OPC UA server ports to authorized networks. User Management and Role-Based Access: Implement user-level permissions to ensure only authorized clients can read/write specific nodes. Suppose you want to simulate a temperature sensor: Create a server with a TemperatureSensor object that contains a Temperature variable. The server updates Temperature every second. A client connects, subscribes, and receives updates in real-time. Add security by requiring a username/password or certificate. This scenario ties together server creation, namespace definition, variable updates, client subscription, and basic security. An OPC UA communication diagram might show: A Server exposing an endpoint and an address space. Clients connecting, browsing, reading/writing variables, and subscribing to data changes.

item.dc:creator: Yangha Park

item.title: Websockets
item.description:
Í≥µÏãù Î¨∏ÏÑú ÎßÅÌÅ¨(pypi v14.1) WebSockets enable real-time, low-latency communication between a client and server. Unlike traditional HTTP request/response cycles, a WebSocket connection remains open, allowing both client and server to push data to each other at any time. Initial Handshake: The communication starts as an HTTP(S) handshake. The client sends an Upgrade: websocket header, and the server responds with 101 Switching Protocols, indicating a successful upgrade. Persistent Connection: Once established, the connection stays open until explicitly closed by either party. No need to re-send headers or re-establish connections on every message. Message Frames: Data is transferred in frames. Frames can be either text or binary. The websockets library abstracts these details, allowing you to simply send/receive text or binary data without manual frame handling. Python‚Äôs asyncio library provides the foundation for asynchronous I/O, which works perfectly with WebSockets for handling multiple simultaneous connections efficiently. The websockets library is one of the most popular choices because it: Fully supports Python‚Äôs async/await syntax. Handles the low-level details of the WebSocket protocol. Offers a simple, intuitive API. Other options: aiohttp: A web framework that includes WebSocket support. FastAPI or Starlette: Modern frameworks that support WebSockets, beneficial for integrating with REST APIs. Tornado: A Python framework with built-in WebSocket support and event loop integration. Ensure you have Python 3.7+ (as asyncio and websockets rely on newer Python features). Install websockets: pip install websockets A simple server that listens for incoming connections and echoes back received messages: import asyncio import websockets async def echo(websocket, path): async for message in websocket: # Echo the received message back to the client await websocket.send(f"Echo from server: {message}") # Start server on localhost:8765 start_server = websockets.serve(echo, "localhost", 8765) asyncio.get_event_loop().run_until_complete(start_server) asyncio.get_event_loop().run_forever() Explanation: websockets.serve(echo, "localhost", 8765) sets up a server on localhost at port 8765. The echo function is a ‚Äúhandler‚Äù that runs whenever a new client connects. It receives messages in an async for loop. The path parameter can be used to differentiate endpoints if you have a reverse proxy or multiple routes, though it‚Äôs not strictly necessary. To connect to the above server: import asyncio import websockets async def client(): uri = "ws://localhost:8765" async with websockets.connect(uri) as websocket: await websocket.send("Hello, Server!") response = await websocket.recv() print("Received from server:", response) asyncio.get_event_loop().run_until_complete(client()) Explanation: The websockets.connect creates a client connection. After sending a message, we recv() and print the echoed response. Network issues or unexpected closures can occur. Always handle exceptions: import websockets from websockets.exceptions import ConnectionClosed, WebSocketException async def safe_client(): uri = "ws://localhost:8765" try: async with websockets.connect(uri) as websocket: await websocket.send("Are you there?") response = await websocket.recv() print(response) except ConnectionClosed: print("Connection was closed by the server or network.") except WebSocketException as e: print("WebSocket exception:", e) Explanation: ConnectionClosed indicates the server closed the connection or a network issue occurred. WebSocketException is a more general error class for WebSocket-related issues. WebSockets can send text (UTF-8) or binary data (raw bytes). Send text: await websocket.send("A text message") Send binary: await websocket.send(b"\x00\x01\x02\x03") On the receiving end, you get either a str (for text) or bytes (for binary). Handle them accordingly: async for message in websocket: if isinstance(message, str): # Process text message elif isinstance(message, bytes): # Process binary message aiohttp provides a request handler-based approach: from aiohttp import web async def websocket_handler(request): ws = web.WebSocketResponse() await ws.prepare(request) async for msg in ws: if msg.type == web.WSMsgType.TEXT: await ws.send_str("Echo: " + msg.data) return ws app = web.Application() app.router.add_get('/ws', websocket_handler) web.run_app(app, host='localhost', port=8765) Explanation: web.WebSocketResponse() upgrades the connection to WebSocket if possible. Use ws.send_str() or ws.send_bytes() for responses. With FastAPI, WebSocket endpoints integrate nicely with API routes: from fastapi import FastAPI, WebSocket app = FastAPI() @app.websocket("/ws") async def websocket_endpoint(websocket: WebSocket): await websocket.accept() while True: data = await websocket.receive_text() await websocket.send_text(f"Server received: {data}") Explanation: websocket.accept() upgrades the connection. await websocket.receive_text() and await websocket.send_text() provide a clean API. Token-based Auth: Include a token (e.g., JWT) in the initial handshake URL or headers. Validate the token before accepting the WebSocket. Session Cookies: If using frameworks like FastAPI, you can read cookies or HTTP headers before upgrading. Access Control: Only allow certain clients to connect based on roles or permissions. Async I/O: asyncio ensures the server can handle many connections concurrently without blocking. Event Loops: Consider using uvloop (a drop-in replacement for asyncio‚Äôs default event loop) to improve performance. Load Balancing: Use a reverse proxy like Nginx or HAProxy. For horizontal scaling, you can run multiple Python processes and have a load balancer distribute WebSocket connections. Backpressure Handling: Implement logic to handle slow clients. If the server sends messages faster than a client can consume, queue them temporarily or drop messages as needed. Rate Limiting and Throttling: Prevent abusive clients from flooding the server by limiting messages per second or total bandwidth. WebSockets are great for chat apps or collaborative environments: Keep track of connected clients in a global list or dictionary. Broadcast messages to all connected clients or specific ‚Äúrooms‚Äù by iterating over these lists. Example: clients = set() async def handler(websocket, path): clients.add(websocket) try: async for message in websocket: # Broadcast this message to all other clients for client in clients: if client != websocket: await client.send(message) finally: clients.remove(websocket) Explanation: This code maintains a clients set. When a new client connects, add it. When they disconnect, remove it. On message receipt, send the message to all other connected clients, creating a simple chat room functionality. WebSockets transmit raw strings or bytes. For structured data: Use JSON: import json # Sending JSON data = {"type": "chat_message", "content": "Hello!"} await websocket.send(json.dumps(data)) # Receiving JSON async for raw_message in websocket: message = json.loads(raw_message) # now 'message' is a Python dict Binary serialization (e.g., Protocol Buffers) for efficiency and reduced bandwidth. Command-line Tools: websocat: websocat ws://localhost:8765 Type messages and see server responses. Browser Developer Tools: Open the console and create a WebSocket: let ws = new WebSocket("ws://localhost:8765"); ws.onmessage = event => console.log("Received:", event.data); ws.onopen = () => ws.send("Hello from the browser!"); Logging and Monitoring: Add logging statements (print or logging module) to track connections, messages, and errors. Use metrics and dashboards (like Prometheus + Grafana) to monitor connection counts, message rates, and errors in production. Encryption: Use wss:// (TLS-secured WebSockets) in production to protect data from eavesdropping. Set up SSL certificates and configure your server with an SSLContext. Input Validation: Validate incoming messages to prevent injection attacks or buffer overflow attempts. Sanitize or check message sizes and formats before processing. Below is a more complete server example that handles multiple clients, uses JSON messages, and demonstrates basic error handling and logging: import asyncio import websockets import json import logging logging.basicConfig(level=logging.INFO) connected_clients = set() async def broadcast(message): # Broadcast a JSON-encoded message to all connected clients if connected_clients: await asyncio.wait([client.send(json.dumps(message)) for client in connected_clients]) async def handler(websocket, path): connected_clients.add(websocket) logging.info(f"New connection: {websocket.remote_address}") try: async for raw_message in websocket: try: data = json.loads(raw_message) logging.info(f"Received message: {data} from {websocket.remote_address}") # Echoing data back with a server timestamp: response = { "type": "response", "data_received": data, "server_time": asyncio.get_event_loop().time() } await broadcast(response) except json.JSONDecodeError: # Send an error message if JSON is invalid error_message = {"type": "error", "message": "Invalid JSON"} await websocket.send(json.dumps(error_message)) except websockets.ConnectionClosed: logging.info(f"Connection closed: {websocket.remote_address}") finally: connected_clients.remove(websocket) start_server = websockets.serve(handler, "localhost", 8765) asyncio.get_event_loop().run_until_complete(start_server) asyncio.get_event_loop().run_forever() Explanation: Maintains a global connected_clients set. Uses broadcast() to send messages to all clients. Tries to parse incoming data as JSON and logs all actions. Gracefully handles closure and removes disconnected clients. Implementing WebSockets in Python involves understanding the protocol, choosing a suitable library, and using asyncio to manage concurrency. The websockets library makes it straightforward to create both servers and clients. Integrating with frameworks like aiohttp or FastAPI allows you to leverage WebSockets alongside REST endpoints. Advanced considerations include authentication, scalability, binary data handling, structured messaging (JSON), and robust error handling. With careful design and testing, WebSockets can power real-time features in chat systems, live dashboards, multiplayer games, and more. To illustrate how a WebSocket client connects and exchanges messages with a server, imagine a diagram showing the handshake and a continuous stream of messages.

item.dc:creator: Yangha Park

item.title: CTE
item.description: A Common Table Expression (CTE) is a temporary, named result set defined within the scope of a single SQL statement. Introduced by the WITH keyword, a CTE helps improve query readability, maintainability, and modularity by allowing you to break down complex queries into smaller, more understandable parts. WITH cte_name AS ( SELECT ... FROM ... WHERE ... ) SELECT ... FROM cte_name; cte_name: A name you assign to the temporary result set. The code inside the parentheses ( ... ) is essentially a subquery that you can reference multiple times in the main query. A CTE is defined before the main query using the WITH clause. Once defined, the CTE acts as a virtual table that exists just for the execution of that query. After the main query finishes running, the CTE no longer exists. It is not persistent or stored in the database schema. Improved Readability and Organization: CTEs allow you to isolate complex logic from the main query. Instead of writing one large, nested query, you can define logical steps within separate CTEs and then reference them, making your SQL code easier to understand and maintain. Reusability within the Same Query: Once defined, you can reference the CTE multiple times within the main query. This can help avoid repeating the same subquery logic multiple times. Multiple CTEs in a Single Query: You can define multiple CTEs separated by commas and then select from them in the final query. This allows for building a sequence of computations step-by-step. Recursive Queries: Some databases support recursive CTEs, which enable you to solve hierarchical or tree-like data structures easily. Recursive CTEs repeatedly reference themselves until a stopping condition is met. WITH EmployeeSalaries AS ( SELECT EmployeeID, FirstName, LastName, Salary, DepartmentID FROM Employees WHERE Salary > 50000 ) SELECT * FROM EmployeeSalaries ORDER BY Salary DESC; Explanation: The CTE EmployeeSalaries extracts employees with a salary over 50,000. The main query then selects from EmployeeSalaries as if it were a regular table. This approach improves clarity compared to embedding the SELECT logic directly in the FROM clause. CTE: Declared using WITH at the start of the statement. Can be referenced multiple times in the subsequent query. Often more readable and easier to maintain. Subquery: Defined inline, usually nested in SELECT, FROM, or WHERE clauses. Each occurrence must be repeated if the logic is needed multiple times. Can make queries harder to read when multiple subqueries are nested. WITH HighEarner AS ( SELECT EmployeeID, FirstName, LastName, Salary FROM Employees WHERE Salary > 70000 ), DepartmentSummary AS ( SELECT DepartmentID, COUNT(*) AS TotalEmployees FROM Employees GROUP BY DepartmentID ) SELECT h.FirstName, h.LastName, h.Salary, d.TotalEmployees FROM HighEarner h JOIN DepartmentSummary d ON h.DepartmentID = d.DepartmentID; Explanation: The first CTE (HighEarner) identifies employees with a salary above 70,000. The second CTE (DepartmentSummary) calculates how many employees are in each department. The main SELECT statement then joins these two CTEs, producing a result that shows each high-earning employee along with the total count of employees in their department. (If supported by your SQL dialect, such as PostgreSQL or SQL Server)WITH RECURSIVE OrgChart AS ( SELECT EmployeeID, ManagerID, FirstName, LastName FROM Employees WHERE ManagerID IS NULL -- start from the top-level manager(s) UNION ALL SELECT e.EmployeeID, e.ManagerID, e.FirstName, e.LastName FROM Employees e JOIN OrgChart o ON e.ManagerID = o.EmployeeID ) SELECT * FROM OrgChart; Explanation: This recursive CTE starts by selecting top-level managers (those with no ManagerID). In the recursive part (after UNION ALL), it repeatedly selects employees whose ManagerID matches an EmployeeID already found in OrgChart, building the hierarchy level by level. CTEs and Optimization: Most relational databases treat CTEs like inline views. Depending on the database, a CTE might or might not be materialized (cached). While CTEs are great for readability, they do not inherently guarantee performance improvements. In some cases, a well-tuned subquery or a different approach may be faster. Indexing: Since CTEs are not physical tables, you cannot index them directly. They rely on indexes on the underlying tables. Complex Queries: When you have a complex query that would benefit from breaking down logic into steps. Repetition Avoidance: When the same logic or computation needs to be reused multiple times in a query. Recursive Solutions: When dealing with hierarchical data and you need a simple way to traverse parent-child relationships. CTEs are powerful tools for structuring queries in a clear, modular fashion. They simplify complex SQL statements, enhance readability, and can provide a more logical flow when dealing with intricate logic or hierarchical data. While not always a performance enhancement, their primary value lies in cleaner, more maintainable SQL code.
item.dc:creator: Yangha Park

item.title: Subqueries, Correlated subqueries
item.description: Subqueries (also known as inner queries) are queries nested inside other SQL statements, such as SELECT, INSERT, UPDATE, or DELETE. They allow you to dynamically use the results of one query as input or conditions for another. Correlated subqueries are a special type of subquery that references one or more columns from the outer query. Unlike a regular subquery, a correlated subquery is evaluated once for each row processed by the outer query, making it more dynamic but potentially less performant. A subquery is a query enclosed in parentheses and embedded inside a larger query. It is often used in WHERE clauses, FROM clauses (as a derived table), or SELECT clauses. Generally, a subquery can be executed independently, and its result is then passed to the outer query. Filtering Results in a WHERE Clause: SELECT EmployeeID, FirstName, LastName FROM Employees WHERE DepartmentID = ( SELECT DepartmentID FROM Departments WHERE DepartmentName = 'Sales' ); Explanation: The subquery finds the DepartmentID for the "Sales" department. The outer query then returns all employees in that department. Using Subqueries in the FROM Clause (Derived Tables): SELECT d.DepartmentName, e.EmployeeCount FROM ( SELECT DepartmentID, COUNT(*) AS EmployeeCount FROM Employees GROUP BY DepartmentID ) e INNER JOIN Departments d ON d.DepartmentID = e.DepartmentID; Explanation: The subquery e aggregates employees by department. The outer query joins this result to the Departments table to retrieve department names alongside employee counts. Subqueries in the SELECT List: SELECT FirstName, LastName, (SELECT COUNT(*) FROM Orders WHERE Orders.EmployeeID = Employees.EmployeeID) AS OrderCount FROM Employees; Explanation: For each employee, the subquery counts how many orders they have processed. Typically executed once, and the result is reused by the outer query. Does not necessarily depend on the outer query‚Äôs current row. In other words, the subquery can stand alone and run independently. A correlated subquery is a subquery that references columns from the outer (parent) query. It means the subquery depends on the current row of the outer query to be evaluated. As a result, a correlated subquery is executed once for each row in the outer query, making it more computationally expensive in many cases. SELECT e.EmployeeID, e.FirstName, e.LastName FROM Employees e WHERE e.Salary > ( SELECT AVG(Salary) FROM Employees e2 WHERE e2.DepartmentID = e.DepartmentID ); Explanation: For each employee e in the outer query, the correlated subquery (SELECT AVG(Salary) FROM Employees e2 WHERE e2.DepartmentID = e.DepartmentID) calculates the average salary for that employee‚Äôs department. Thus, the subquery depends on e.DepartmentID, a value in the outer query, changing the subquery‚Äôs criteria as the outer query progresses through its rows. The outer query selects a row. The correlated subquery runs, using values from that row, and returns a result. The outer query uses that result to determine if the row meets the conditions. This process repeats for each row of the outer query‚Äôs result set. Because a correlated subquery runs once per outer row, it can be much slower on large datasets. In many cases, it can be optimized by rewriting the query using joins, temporary tables, or window functions. Identify When Correlated Subqueries Are Necessary: If your logic requires a per-row lookup that depends on the outer row, a correlated subquery might be needed. For example, checking if an employee‚Äôs salary is greater than the average salary of their department (calculated at runtime). Optimize Correlated Subqueries: Consider rewriting the query using JOINs, COMMON TABLE EXPRESSIONS (CTEs), or window functions if possible. Example transformation using a CTE and a join: WITH DeptAvgSalary AS ( SELECT DepartmentID, AVG(Salary) AS AvgDeptSalary FROM Employees GROUP BY DepartmentID ) SELECT e.EmployeeID, e.FirstName, e.LastName FROM Employees e JOIN DeptAvgSalary das ON e.DepartmentID = das.DepartmentID WHERE e.Salary > das.AvgDeptSalary; This avoids the per-row computation and might run faster. Indexing for Performance: If you cannot avoid correlated subqueries, ensure that the columns used in the subquery‚Äôs conditions are indexed, which can mitigate performance issues. Subqueries and correlated subqueries are powerful SQL techniques that allow for sophisticated queries without overly complex joins or intermediate tables. Regular subqueries are independent and can be used to filter, aggregate, or create derived tables for the outer query. Correlated subqueries depend on the outer query and are evaluated once per row, making them more flexible but potentially less performant. When properly understood and applied, these constructs can simplify SQL logic and help you write more dynamic and powerful queries.
item.dc:creator: Yangha Park

item.title: WINDOW
item.description: A window function is a special type of SQL function that performs calculations across a set of rows related to the current row. Unlike aggregate functions, which collapse multiple rows into a single output row, window functions return a result for every row in the queried set, while still allowing for row-by-row computations over a specified "window" of data. The "window" is a logical partition of the query result set. You define it using the OVER clause, which typically includes: PARTITION BY: Divides the data into groups (partitions) based on one or more columns. Each partition is processed independently by the window function. ORDER BY: Defines the logical order of rows within each partition, enabling functions to reference preceding or following rows. Do Not Collapse Rows: Unlike GROUP BY aggregates, window functions produce an output row for every input row. Each row retains its detail while still benefitting from aggregate-like calculations. Reference Multiple Rows: They can access "neighboring" rows‚Äô data relative to the current row. For example, LAG() and LEAD() retrieve values from preceding or following rows, while ranking functions assign a rank or a row number within each partition. Flexible Calculations: Window functions enable running totals, moving averages, cumulative sums, and advanced statistical computations without complex self-joins or subqueries. Aggregate Functions as Window Functions: AVG(), SUM(), COUNT(), MAX(), MIN() When used with OVER(), these functions can produce cumulative sums or rolling averages. Ranking Functions: RANK(), DENSE_RANK(), ROW_NUMBER() Assign rankings to rows within partitions, useful for top-N queries, ordered subsets, and pagination. Value Functions: LAG() and LEAD() Allow you to compare current row values to prior or subsequent row values. Useful for trend analysis, price changes, or time-series comparisons. Analytical Functions: NTILE(), FIRST_VALUE(), LAST_VALUE() Create buckets of data or identify boundary values within each partition. Calculating a Running Total:SELECT EmployeeID, Sales, SUM(Sales) OVER (ORDER BY SalesDate) AS RunningTotal FROM DailySales; Explanation: For each row, SUM(Sales) OVER (ORDER BY SalesDate) calculates the cumulative sales up to that point in time, without losing the granularity of the individual rows. Determining a Row‚Äôs Position Within a Partition:SELECT DepartmentID, EmployeeID, Salary, RANK() OVER (PARTITION BY DepartmentID ORDER BY Salary DESC) AS SalaryRank FROM Employees; Explanation: For each department, employees are ranked by their salary. Employees with the highest salary in each department receive a rank of 1. Although not required for every window function, a window frame allows you to further specify the subset of rows considered by the function relative to the current row. For example: SELECT EmployeeID, Salary, AVG(Salary) OVER ( ORDER BY HireDate ROWS BETWEEN 2 PRECEDING AND CURRENT ROW ) AS MovingAvgSalary FROM Employees; This considers only the current row and the two rows before it when calculating the average. Window functions can simplify queries and often perform more efficiently than equivalent self-joins or subqueries. Proper indexing on partitioning and ordering columns can further improve performance. Window functions are powerful analytical tools that enhance SQL‚Äôs capability to perform complex calculations without losing the detail of individual rows. By leveraging PARTITION BY, ORDER BY, and optional window frames, you can write sophisticated analytical queries for time-series data, financial reporting, and other data analysis tasks.
item.dc:creator: Yangha Park

item.title: LEAD, LAG
item.description: LEAD and LAG are window functions that allow you to access subsequent or previous row values in a dataset without writing self-joins or complex subqueries. They are commonly used in analytics and reporting to compare current row values against future or past row values within a defined ordering. LEAD(column_name, offset, default) OVER (PARTITION BY partition_column ORDER BY order_column) LAG(column_name, offset, default) OVER (PARTITION BY partition_column ORDER BY order_column) column_name: The column from which you want to retrieve the lead/lag value. offset: An integer indicating how many rows ahead (LEAD) or behind (LAG) you want to look. Default is usually 1 if not specified. default: A value returned if the lead/lag row does not exist (e.g., when you are at the last row and you use LEAD, or at the first row and you use LAG). PARTITION BY: (Optional) Divides the result set into partitions and applies the window function to each partition independently. ORDER BY: Specifies the order of the rows within each partition. The LEAD/LAG functions operate based on this ordering. 1. Using LEAD to Compare a Value to the Next RowSELECT EmployeeID, HireDate, LEAD(HireDate, 1) OVER (ORDER BY HireDate) AS NextHireDate FROM Employees; Explanation: For each row, this query returns the HireDate of the next row in the ordering. The result might help you determine how much time elapsed between consecutive hires. 2. Using LAG to Compare a Value to the Previous RowSELECT EmployeeID, HireDate, LAG(HireDate, 1) OVER (ORDER BY HireDate) AS PreviousHireDate FROM Employees; Explanation: For each row, this query returns the HireDate of the previous record in the result set. You can use this to analyze trends (e.g., difference in hire intervals or sales figures over time). 3. Partitioning the DataSELECT DepartmentID, EmployeeID, HireDate, LAG(HireDate) OVER (PARTITION BY DepartmentID ORDER BY HireDate) AS PreviousHireInDepartment FROM Employees; Explanation: Here, employees are grouped by DepartmentID. The LAG function only looks at previous hires within the same department, providing a department-wise historical view. 4. Handling Missing Rows with a Default ValueSELECT EmployeeID, Sales, LAG(Sales, 1, 0) OVER (ORDER BY SalesDate) AS PreviousSales FROM DailySales; Explanation: If LAG cannot find a previous row (e.g., for the first record), it will return 0 instead of NULL or nothing. This can help maintain consistent calculations, avoiding NULL values. Simplicity: Eliminates the need for self-joins or complex subselects when comparing rows. Performance: Typically more efficient than joining a table to itself, especially on large datasets. Flexibility: Works seamlessly with other window functions like RANK, DENSE_RANK, and ROW_NUMBER to perform advanced analytical queries.
item.dc:creator: Yangha Park

item.title: SQL Syntax
item.description: SQL (Structured Query Language) is the standard language used to communicate and manipulate relational databases. It allows you to create, read, update, and delete data within database tables, as well as define their structure and relationships. Understanding SQL syntax is crucial for any work involving data analysis, backend development, or database administration. A relational database organizes data into tables (relations), which consist of rows and columns. Each table represents an entity (e.g., "Customers," "Orders") and each row represents a record in that table. Columns define attributes of these records (e.g., Customer Name, Order Date). While SQL is standardized by ANSI/ISO, vendors often implement dialect-specific features. Common dialects include: MySQL: Popular open-source database. PostgreSQL: Advanced open-source database with rich features. Microsoft SQL Server: Enterprise-level database management system from Microsoft. Oracle Database: Robust enterprise-level database system known for scalability. Core syntax is consistent across dialects, but certain functions, data types, and keywords may differ. DDL commands define or alter the structure of the database. They include commands like CREATE, ALTER, and DROP. CREATE DATABASE: Syntax: CREATE DATABASE database_name; CREATE TABLE: Syntax: CREATE TABLE table_name ( column_name1 data_type constraints, column_name2 data_type constraints, ... ); Example: CREATE TABLE Employees ( EmployeeID INT PRIMARY KEY, FirstName VARCHAR(50), LastName VARCHAR(50), HireDate DATE ); ALTER TABLE: Modify an existing table structure. Add a column: ALTER TABLE Employees ADD Email VARCHAR(100); Modify a column: ALTER TABLE Employees MODIFY Email VARCHAR(150); Drop a column: ALTER TABLE Employees DROP COLUMN Email; DROP TABLE: Deletes a table and all its data permanently. DROP TABLE Employees; DROP DATABASE: Removes a database entirely. DROP DATABASE company_db; DML commands manipulate the data stored in tables. Common DML commands include INSERT, UPDATE, and DELETE. INSERT: Add new rows to a table. Syntax: INSERT INTO table_name (column1, column2, ...) VALUES (value1, value2, ...); Example: INSERT INTO Employees (EmployeeID, FirstName, LastName, HireDate) VALUES (1, 'John', 'Doe', '2024-01-15'); UPDATE: Modify existing records. Syntax: UPDATE table_name SET column1 = value1, column2 = value2 WHERE condition; Example: UPDATE Employees SET Email = 'john.doe@example.com' WHERE EmployeeID = 1; DELETE: Remove rows that meet a specific condition. Syntax: DELETE FROM table_name WHERE condition; Example: DELETE FROM Employees WHERE EmployeeID = 1; SELECT: The most common SQL command used to query data from one or more tables. Syntax: SELECT column1, column2, ... FROM table_name WHERE conditions GROUP BY grouping_columns HAVING conditions_on_aggregates ORDER BY sorting_columns; Retrieve certain columns: SELECT FirstName, LastName FROM Employees; Retrieve all columns: SELECT * FROM Employees; WHERE: Limits which rows are returned. SELECT FirstName, LastName FROM Employees WHERE HireDate > '2024-01-01'; ORDER BY: Sorts results ascending (ASC) or descending (DESC). SELECT FirstName, LastName, HireDate FROM Employees ORDER BY HireDate DESC; COUNT, SUM, AVG, MAX, MIN SELECT COUNT(*) AS TotalEmployees FROM Employees; GROUP BY: Aggregate functions often used with GROUP BY. SELECT HireDate, COUNT(*) AS HiresOnDate FROM Employees GROUP BY HireDate; HAVING: Filters groups after aggregation. SELECT HireDate, COUNT(*) AS HiresOnDate FROM Employees GROUP BY HireDate HAVING COUNT(*) > 1; JOIN: Combine rows from multiple tables based on related columns. INNER JOIN: Returns matching rows in both tables. SELECT e.FirstName, e.LastName, d.DepartmentName FROM Employees e INNER JOIN Departments d ON e.DepartmentID = d.DepartmentID; LEFT JOIN: Returns all rows from left table, and matched rows from right table. RIGHT JOIN: Returns all rows from right table, and matched rows from left table. FULL OUTER JOIN: Returns all rows from both tables, matched or not. A subquery is a query nested inside another query. SELECT FirstName, LastName FROM Employees WHERE EmployeeID IN ( SELECT EmployeeID FROM Projects WHERE ProjectStatus = 'Active' ); GRANT: Gives permissions to a user or role. GRANT SELECT ON Employees TO analyst; REVOKE: Removes permissions. REVOKE SELECT ON Employees FROM analyst; A transaction is a sequence of SQL operations treated as a single unit of work. COMMIT: Saves changes made during the transaction. ROLLBACK: Undoes all changes made in the transaction if an error occurs. START TRANSACTION; UPDATE Employees SET FirstName = 'Jane' WHERE EmployeeID = 2; COMMIT; Uniquely identifies each row in a table. Only one primary key per table, which can consist of one or multiple columns. Establish relationships between tables. A foreign key in one table references a primary key in another table. NOT NULL: Prevents a column from having NULL values. UNIQUE: Ensures all values in a column are distinct. CHECK: Ensures that values meet a specific condition. DEFAULT: Assigns a default value if no value is provided. An index speeds up queries by allowing the database engine to find data faster. Trade-off: Faster reads, but slower writes (INSERT/UPDATE/DELETE) due to maintenance of the index. CREATE INDEX idx_employees_lastname ON Employees (LastName); A view is a virtual table based on the result of a query. CREATE VIEW ActiveEmployees AS SELECT FirstName, LastName FROM Employees WHERE Status = 'Active'; Stored Procedures: Precompiled collections of SQL statements stored in the database. Functions: Similar to procedures but return a value. Syntax varies by SQL dialect. Perform calculations across sets of rows related to the current row without collapsing them into a single output row. SELECT FirstName, LastName, RANK() OVER (ORDER BY HireDate) AS HireOrder FROM Employees; SQL syntax provides a powerful and intuitive way to interact with relational databases. By mastering DDL, DML, and SELECT queries, you can handle most database operations. Advanced features like indexing, views, and stored procedures enhance performance and maintainability. Regular practice, along with consulting official documentation and reputable guides, will solidify your SQL skills.

item.title: Unit 2. Progress Update
item.description: distribution rights exclusive license reach an agreement term sheet final draft agreement We had a meeting this pas Monday to discuss some outstanding issues on the table. They‚Äôre trying to play hardball. Hopefully we‚Äôll square away any remaining issues then. Hello, Yangha! The sentences you said sound really good! Just a few minor adjustments and they'll be even more natural English sentences. In the first sentence, "By the end of two year.", you should say "two years" instead of "two year". "Year" is a plural noun, so you need to use "years"! In the second sentence, "We need to negotiate for suppliers for hardware supplies.", you can remove "for" and say "We need to negotiate with suppliers for hardware supplies." It sounds more natural. "Negotiate with" means "ÌòëÏÉÅÌïòÎã§", and using "with" instead of "for" is a more natural expression. In the third sentence, "We have to delay all the schedule.", it would be better to say "We have to delay the whole schedule." In Korean, "all" is often used to mean "Ï†ÑÏ≤¥", but in English, "the whole" is more natural. In the fourth sentence, "I had a project to build database.", you need to add "a" before "database" to say "I had a project to build a database." "Database" is a countable noun, so you need to add "a" in front of it. In the last sentence, "They are not enough to build database by themselves.", you can replace "enough" with "sufficient" and say "They are not sufficient to build database by themselves." "Enough" should be used as an adjective, and "sufficient" is more natural as a noun. Yangha, if you carefully review each sentence and practice, you'll be able to develop even better English skills! By the end of the year We need to negotiate for suppliers for hardware supplies. ‚Üí We need to negotiate with suppliers for hardware procurement. We have to delay all the schedule. ‚Üí We need to delay all schedules. I had a project to build database. ‚Üí I worked on project to build a database. They are not enough to build database by themselves. ‚ÜíThey don‚Äôt have enough expertise to build a database independently.

item.title: Unit 1. Announcing a new project
item.description: get a foothold in financial modeling have a consensus convene a meeting adjourn a meeting shelve a topic adopt resolutions have a quorum to vote -We have a new smart medical decive in the works. We have a lot groundwork to cover. We might be able to do it if we work around the clock. Hello, Yangha! The sentences you mentioned, if you adjust them a little, they will sound more natural and accurate. The first sentence "We have new project to develop." It would be better to put 'a' in front of 'new project'. "We have a new project to develop." This sounds much more natural! The second sentence "I have a project to build a data base to production line." If you put 'for' between 'data base' and 'production line', you can convey a clearer meaning. "I have a project to build a data base for the production line." This sounds more natural! The last sentence "I am kind of a hard worker." is excellent! You can also say "I am a hard worker." without "kind of", which sounds natural and more confident. Yangha, if you put a little effort into building sentences, you will improve a lot! Keep practicing, correct your mistakes, and be confident! We have new project to develop. ‚Üí We have a new project to develop. I have a project to build a database to production line. ‚Üí I have a project to build a database for the production line. I am kind of a hard worker. ‚Üí I‚Äôm a hard worker. I always feel uncomfortable to speak in English unlike to write in English. I think the why I‚Äôm like this is because of my character, I mean, introverted character. I feel the need of having more chances to speak in English. And it feels like this time is when I have to learn how to have a small talk with other people.I always feel uncomfortable speaking in English, unlike when I‚Äôm writing. I think it‚Äôs partly because of my personality‚ÄîI‚Äôm more on the introverted side. I feel the need for more opportunities to practice speaking in English, and it seems like now is the right time for me to learn how to make small talk with others.
